case_name: Writ Petitions Nos. 362, 363 of 1972 and Civil Appeals Nos. 107, 968 to 971, 1185, 1168 of 1972

facts.text: Notification under section 4 of the Land Acquisition Act was issued on November 13, 1950, stating that 34,070 acres of land was needed for planned development of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: A numberification under s. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act  hereinafter referred to as the Act  was issued on November 13, 1950, stating that an area of 34,070 acres of land was needed for a public purpose, viz., the planned development of Delhi.

facts.text: About six thousand objections were filed under section 5A between 1959 and 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Between 1959 and 1961, about six thousand objections were filed under s. 5A of the Act. The objec- tions were civerruled.

facts.text: Objections under section 5A were overruled.

anchor.surface_text: The objec- tions were civerruled. On March 18, 1966, the declaration under S. 6 of the Act was published in respect of a portion of the area.

facts.text: Declaration under section 6 published on March 18, 1966 for a portion of the area.

anchor.surface_text: On March 18, 1966, the declaration under S. 6 of the Act was published in respect of a portion of the area. Thereafter, in 1970, numberices were issued under s. 9 1  of the, Act

facts.text: Notices under section 9(1) issued in 1970 requiring appellants to state objections to compensation assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, in 1970, numberices were issued under s. 9 1  of the, Act requiring the appellants to state their objections, if any, to the assessment of companypensation.

facts.text: Appellants challenged validity of acquisition proceedings before Delhi High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereupon challenged the validity of proceedings for acquisition before the, High Court of Delhi on the following, grounds

facts.text: Delhi High Court dismissed writ petitions on September 24, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated the September 24, 1971 of the Delhi High Court in L.PsAs. NC3. 172, 177, 151, 170, 171 and 152 of 1971 respectively.

facts.text: Delhi High Court judgment and order dated April 17, 1971 in L.P.A. No. 94 of 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1168 of 1972. Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment and Order dated the 17th April, 1971 of the Delhi High Court in L.P.A. No. 94 of 1971.

facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 362 and 363 of 1972 filed under Article 32.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 362 363 of 1972. Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 107, 968 to 971 and 1185 of 1972 by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 107, 968 to 971 and 1185 of 1972. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated the September 24, 1971 of the Delhi High Court

facts.text: Petitioners claimed acquisition was for companies, requiring Part VII compliance.

facts.text: Petitioners claimed no part of compensation from public exchequer, so not public purpose.

anchor.surface_text: 2  since numberpart of the companypensation payable came from the public exchequer, the acquisition was number for a public purpose

facts.text: Petitioners claimed unreasonable delay between s.4 notification and s.9 notices violating Article 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: 3  that the proceedings for acquisition violated the fundamental right of the, appellants under Article 19 1  f  as there was unreasonable delay between the publication of the numberification under s. 4 and the issue of the numberices under s. 9 of the Act

facts.text: Influx of displaced persons from West Pakistan into Delhi in 1947 aggravated housing problem.

anchor.surface_text: The influx of displaced persons in 1947 from West Pakistan into Delhi aggravated the problem of housing accommodation in Delhi.

facts.text: Government allotted large portion of acquired land to cooperative housing societies.

anchor.surface_text: From the companynter affidavit filed on behalf of the Government, it is clear that the Government have allotted a large portion of the land after the acquisition proceedings were finalised to Cooperative lousing societies.

facts.text: Several writ petitions filed in 1966 and 1967 challenging acquisition.

anchor.surface_text: Several writ petitions were also filed in 1966 and 1967 challenging the validity of the acquisition proceedings.

facts.text: Appellants approached High Court in 1970 when s.9 notices issued.

anchor.surface_text: They approached the High Court with their writ petitions only in 1970 when the numberices under s. 9 were issued to them.

facts.text: No Master Plan or Zonal Plan existed on date of s.4 notification.

anchor.surface_text: the public purpose specified in the numberification issued under s. 4, namely, the planned development of Delhi was vague as neither a Master Plan number a Zonal Plan was in existence on the date of the numberification

facts.text: Notification under s.4 issued by Chief Commissioner of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: since the proceedings were initiated by the Chief Commissioner of Delhi, the proceedings were ab initio invalid.

facts.text: Major portion of land allotted without development to cooperative housing societies which are companies.

anchor.surface_text: as the major portion of the,land acquired was allotted without any development to companyperative housing societies which were companypanies within the definition of the word Company in the Act

facts.text: Delhi High Court Single Judge and Division Bench found no inordinate delay.

anchor.surface_text: Both the learned Single Judge as well as the Division Bench of the High Court were of the view that there was numberinordinate delay on the part of the Government

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed writ petitions on ground of laches and delay.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petitions are liable to be dismissed on the ground of laches and delay on the part of the petitioners

holdings.text: The writ petitions are liable to be dismissed on the ground of laches and delay on the part of the petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petitions are liable to be dismissed on the ground of laches and delay on the part of the petitioners see Tilokchand Motichand and Others v. H. B. Munshi and Another 1  and Rabindranath Bose and Others v. Union of India Others 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: No timely challenge after s.6 publication in 1966 or s.9 notices in 1970; third party rights vested; cites Tilokchand and Rabindranath.

holdings.text: It is only necessary to state in the notification under s.4 that the land is needed for a public purpose; 'planned development of Delhi' is sufficiently particularized for large area acquisition enabling s.5A objections.

anchor.surface_text: According to the section, therefore, it is only necessary to state in the numberification that the land is needed for a public purpose. The wording of s. 5A would make it further clear that all that is necessary to be specified in a numberification under s. 4 is that the land is needed for a public purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of s.4 requires only 'public purpose'; for large tracts, general description suffices; cites Munshi Singh and Arnold Rodricks; enables meaningful s.5A objections.

holdings.text: Even assuming public purpose insufficiently specified, challenge barred by laches as not raised timely after s.6 declaration.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming for the moment that the public purpose was number sufficiently specified in the numberification, did the appellants make a grievance of it at the appropriate time?

holdings.reasoning_summary: No objection post-s.6 in 1966; first challenge in 1970; dilatory tactics not permitted; protects reliance on proceedings.

holdings.text: There was no inordinate delay on the part of the Government in completing the acquisition proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Both the learned Single Judge as well as the Division Bench of the High Court were of the view that there was numberinordinate delay on the part of the Government in companypleting the acquisition proceedings. We are number persuaded to companye to a different companyclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Time taken justified by 6000 s.5A objections and 1966-67 writ petitions; lower courts concurred.

holdings.text: s.23 of the Land Acquisition Act does not impose unreasonable restriction under Article 19(1)(f); challenge limited to procedural reasonableness and barred by Article 31(5)(a) as pre-Constitution law.

anchor.surface_text: Article 31 5   a  provides Nothing in clause  2  shall affect--  a  the provisions of any existing law other than a law to which the provisions of clause  6  apply,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.31(5)(a) precludes adequacy challenge; s.23 substantive provision, not procedural; cites R.C. Cooper.

holdings.text: Even assuming Chief Commissioner lacked authority under s.15 DDA, challenge to s.4 notification barred by laches.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think it necessary to go into the question whether the power to acquire the land under s. 15 was delegated by the Central Government to the Chief Commissioner of Delhi.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Laches precludes questioning notification validity; relates to s.4 initiation.

holdings.text: Land acquisition for planned development permissible before Master Plan or development area declaration under DDA s.12.

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 is companycerned only with the planned development. It has numberhing to do with acquisition of property acquisition generally precedes development.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.12 regulates development post-acquisition; no bar on pre-plan acquisition; cites Patna Improvement Trust.

holdings.text: Acquisition not for companies requiring Part VII compliance despite post-acquisition allotment to cooperative housing societies.

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that after the acquisition the Government proposed to hand over, or, in fact, handed over, a portion of the property acquired for development to the companyperative housing societies would number make the acquisition one for companypany.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purpose at acquisition time is planned development; post-acq transfer doesn't alter; lower courts agreed.

holdings.text: Compensation for acquisition not provided by cooperative societies.

anchor.surface_text: Nor are we satisfied that there is any merit in the companytention that companypensation to be paid for the acquisition came from the companysideration paid by the companyperative societies.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Counter-affidavit averments; no evidence of society funding.

precedents.citation: Munshi Singh and Others v. Union of India, etc. 1 1973 1 SCR 973, at 975 and 984

anchor.surface_text: This Court has laid down that it is necessary to specify the particular public purpose in the numberification for which the land is needed or likely to be needed as, otherwise, the matters specified in sub-section ( 2 ) of s. 4 cannot be carried out. in Munshi Singh and Others v. Union of India, etc. 1 the Court said It is apparent from sub-section ( 2 ) of s. 4 that the public purpose which has to be stated in sub-section ( 1 ) of s. 4 has to be particularized because, unless that is done, the various matters which were mentioned in sub-section ( 2 ) cannot be carried out and if the public purpose stated in s. 4 ( 1 ) is planned development, without anything more, it is extremely difficult to companyprehend how all the matters set out in sub-section ( 2 ) can be carried out by the officer companycerned.

precedents.case_name: Munshi Singh v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: public purpose in notification under Section 4 must be particularized to enable carrying out of matters in sub-section (2) and effective objections under Section 5A
precedents.cited_holding: It is apparent from sub-section (2) of s. 4 that the public purpose which has to be stated in sub-section (1) of s. 4 has to be particularized because, unless that is done, the various matters which were mentioned in sub-section (2) cannot be carried out and if the public purpose stated in s. 4(1) is planned development, without anything more, it is extremely difficult to comprehend how all the matters set out in sub-section (2) can be carried out by the officer concerned.

precedents.citation: Arnold Rodricks and Another v. State of Maharashtra and Others 2 1966 3 S.C.R. 885

anchor.surface_text: We think that the question whether the purpose specified in a numberification under s. 4 is sufficient to enable an objection to be filed under s. 5A would depend upon the facts and circumstances of each case. In Arnold Rodricks and Another v. State of Maharashtra and Others 2 , this Court held that a numberification under s. 4 of the Act which stated that the land was needed for Development and utilization of the said lands as an industrial and residential area was sufficient specification of public purpose.

precedents.case_name: Arnold Rodricks v. State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: specification of public purpose as 'Development and utilization of the said lands as an industrial and residential area' in Section 4 notification is sufficient
precedents.cited_holding: a notification under s. 4 of the Act which stated that the land was needed for Development and utilization of the said lands as an industrial and residential area was sufficient specification of public purpose

precedents.citation: Munshi Singh Others v. Union of India supra

anchor.surface_text: In the concluding portion of the judgment in Munshi Singh Others v. Union of India supra , it was observed In matters of this nature we would have taken due numberice of laches on the part of the appellants while granting the above relief but we are satisfied that so far as the present appellants are companycerned they have number been guilty of laches, delay or acquiescence, at any stage. We do number think that the appellants were vigilant.

precedents.case_name: Munshi Singh v. Union of India
precedents.cited_holding: In matters of this nature we would have taken due notice of laches on the part of the appellants while granting the above relief but we are satisfied that so far as the present appellants are concerned they have not been guilty of laches, delay or acquiescence, at any stage.

precedents.citation: Tilokchand Motichand and Others v. H. B. Munshi and Another 1 1969 2 S.C.R. 824

anchor.surface_text: The writ petitions are liable to be dismissed on the ground of laches and delay on the part of the petitioners see Tilokchand Motichand and Others v. H. B. Munshi and Another 1 and Rabindranath Bose and Others v. Union of India Others 2 .

precedents.case_name: Tilokchand Motichand v. H. B. Munshi
precedents.cited_proposition: laches and delay bar challenge to acquisition notifications

anchor.surface_text: The writ petitions are liable to be dismissed on the ground of laches and delay on the part of the petitioners see Tilokchand Motichand and Others v. H. B. Munshi and Another 1 and Rabindranath Bose and Others v. Union of India Others 2 . precedents.case_name: Rabindranath Bose v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: laches and delay bar challenge to acquisition notifications

precedents.citation: R. C. Cooper v. Union of India 1 1970 3 S.C.R. 530, at 577

anchor.surface_text: In R. C. Cooper v. Union of India 1 , this Court has observed that although a law for acquisition of property must pass the test of Article 19(5), the challenge to the law would ordinarily be limited to the question of procedural unreasonableness. This is what the Court said . . . Where the law provides for compulsory acquisition of property for a public purpose, it may be presumed that the acquisition or the law relating thereto imposes a reasonable restriction in the interest of the general public.

precedents.case_name: R. C. Cooper v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: challenge to acquisition law under Article 19(1)(f) limited to procedural unreasonableness; substantive reasonableness presumed if public purpose
precedents.cited_holding: Where the law provides for compulsory acquisition of property for a public purpose, it may be presumed that the acquisition or the law relating thereto imposes a reasonable restriction in the interest of the general public. If there is no public purpose to sustain compulsory acquisition, the law violates Art. 31(2). If the acquisition is for a public purpose, substantive reasonableness of the restriction which includes deprivation may, unless otherwise established, be presumed, but enquiry into reasonableness of the procedural provisions will not be excluded.

precedents.citation: Patna Improvement Trust v. Smt. Lakshmi Devi and Others 1 1963 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 812

anchor.surface_text: It is true that there could be no planned development of Delhi except in accordance with the provisions of Delhi Development Act after that Act came into force, but there was no inhibition in acquiring land for planned development of Delhi under the Act before the Master Plan was ready see the decision in Patna Improvement Trust v. Smt. Lakshmi Devi and Others 1 .

precedents.case_name: Patna Improvement Trust v. Lakshmi Devi
precedents.cited_proposition: land can be acquired for planned development before the Master Plan is ready
